libs.java.extension.distributedmap

Class DistributedMap<K,V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • libs.java.extension.distributedmap.DistributedMap<K,V>
  • Type Parameters:
    K - it is always a String. It avoid serialization/deserialization of key on operation, because most of map operations work on key, it makes it fast to use predefined type. Second current implementation uses Redis as data store which has inbuilt hash support for string key.
    V - Value of the key. It can be any java type. Currently it is converted to JSON before storing to Redis which makes it easier to read/view data directly at redis
    Simple usage -
    Map map = DistributedMap.newMap("mymap", new HashMap(), 1000 (local key limit), Data.class, redisip, redisport);
    use normal map operations.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.util.Map<java.lang.String,V>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DistributedRedisMap

    public abstract class DistributedMap<K,V>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.util.Map<java.lang.String,V>
    A decorated map with support to distributed operations on map. Current implementation uses redis (See DistributedRedisMap) as shared storage for map data. Basic features this map support -
    1. Limit on Data which user want to be available in local map. Use value 0, if you don't want any data stored locally in process
    2. Data available to in memory is updated data even if updated in another process (eventually lastest updated data)
    3. Data propagation can take some time, so don't depend on accurate data in all the process
    4. Local data key limit does not mean that data is available only on local, it is always stored in shared memory (Redis). At any moment all data is always available in Redis
    5. If redis has data already available, new process does not overwrite old data, if you want afresh for that particular map, clear that either using map operation or directly at Redis
    6. Any update, deletion of key is propagated to all the communicating process
    7. On read of data which is not available in local map, it is copied from shared memory (if available) to local (if local key limit allows) and returned.
    8. "<>", "><", "~~" patterns are used to publish events, and used in parsing, these should not be part of key or value fields See Word Document (How it works) for details of map operations.
    Author:
    Kuldeep
